page.title: 11RHYMNEY VALLEY-ECOLOGY (1)
page.content: Over the last decade or so, land in Rhymney, which has been in the past used for industry, has been reclaimed and it is pleasing to note that considerable success has been achieved.Once again, both flora and fauna are beginning to re-establish themselves in many areas.Sightings have been made of species which are not common in any part of the country. Plants from old farm pastures are now beginning to establish themselves in mining areas: yellow rattle,wild thyme and the trefoil family can seen as can a wide variety of grasses. There has been an increase in the butterfly population due mainly to an increase in larval food.Although the cabbage white has probably always been present there are now peacock and Red Admirals,Tortoise Shells and Painted Ladies.
